elements.content: Five new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), {[Zn2(BPPA)2­(BDC)2]­·6H2O} n (1), {[Cd3(BPPA)­(BDC)2­(DMF)2]­·DMF­·3H2O} n (2), {[Zn­(BPPA)­(NDC)1/2­(HCO2)]} n (3), {[Zn3(BPPA)3­(TFBDC)3]­·H2O} n (4), and {[Cd2(BPPA)2­(TFBDC)2]} n (5), have been synthesized from the self-assembly of the “V-shape” BPPA ligand with Zn/Cd metal salts, incorporating coligands (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, TFBDC = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid, BPPA = bis­(4-(pyridine-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). Compound 1 is a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network with sra topology. Compound 2 is the first 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology, which is reported only non-interpenetration before. Compound 3 is a one-dimensional chain by utilizing a “longer” rigid H2NDC coligand. Via a “fatter” rigid TFBDC ligand, we control interpenetration by one-pot synthesis. Both compounds 4 and 5 are non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 frameworks, and the 6T8 topology has rarely been reported in MOFs before. Interestingly, carboxyl groups in 1–5 adopt various coordinate modes. Luminescent properties of 1–5 have also been explored, and the emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 are longer than compounds 1–3 and free ligands because of a fluorescent synergistic effect. This may provide an feasible way to exploit materials with long emission decay lifetimes.
elements.clean_text: Five new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), {[Zn2(BPPA)2(BDC)2]⋅6H2O} n  (1), {[Cd3(BPPA)(BDC)2(DMF)2]⋅DMF⋅3H2O} n  (2), {[Zn(BPPA)(NDC)1/2(HCO2)]} n  (3), {[Zn3(BPPA)3(TFBDC)3]⋅H2O} n  (4), and {[Cd2(BPPA)2(TFBDC)2]} n  (5), have been synthesized from the self-assembly of the "V-shape" BPPA ligand with Zn/Cd metal salts, incorporating coligands (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, TFBDC = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid, BPPA = bis(4-(pyridine-4-yl)phenyl)amine, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). Compound 1 is a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network with sra topology. Compound 2 is the first 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology, which is reported only non-interpenetration before. Compound 3 is a one-dimensional chain by utilizing a "longer" rigid H2NDC coligand. Via a "fatter" rigid TFBDC ligand, we control interpenetration by one-pot synthesis. Both compounds 4 and 5 are non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 frameworks, and the 6T8 topology has rarely been reported in MOFs before. Interestingly, carboxyl groups in 1-5 adopt various coordinate modes. Luminescent properties of 1-5 have also been explored, and the emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 are longer than compounds 1-3 and free ligands because of a fluorescent synergistic effect. This may provide an feasible way to exploit materials with long emission decay lifetimes.

elements.content: Five compounds 1−5 with novel architectures were synthesized from the self-assembly of a new “V-shape” ligand with Zn/Cd metal salts. Utilizing a “fatter” coligand, we successfully control interpenetration. Luminescent properties of 1−5 have also been tested, and the emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 are longer than compounds 1−3 and free ligands because of a fluorescent synergistic effect.
elements.clean_text: Five compounds 1-5 with novel architectures were synthesized from the self-assembly of a new "V-shape" ligand with Zn/Cd metal salts. Utilizing a "fatter" coligand, we successfully control interpenetration. Luminescent properties of 1-5 have also been tested, and the emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 are longer than compounds 1-3 and free ligands because of a fluorescent synergistic effect.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are booming materials with multifarious properties, such as gas adsorption, drug delivery, fluorescence, ion exchange, heterogeneous catealysis, and solvatochromism. Most of these properties rely on the sizes of the pores or channels in MOFs. And interpenetration or not is the key factor to affect the sizes of potential channels. Many groups have realized how to control interpenetration, though it is challenging. The construction of networks with interpenetration is based on supramolecular interactions, such as van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonding, and π–π stacking, not via chemical bonds. However, the interpenetrated networks cannot be separated without breakage of bonds. To our knowledge, interpenetration can be controlled via different parameters, such as reaction temperature, reaction concentration, ligands design/modification, template, coordinated or uncoordinated solvent removal/addition, and layer-by-layer assembly. As far as we know, more attention has been paid to complicated organic ligands due to their various coordinated modes and ability to produce novel structures. However, most syntheses of these ligands are fussy, which requires much effort to achieve industrialization or practical application.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are booming materials with multifarious properties, such as gas adsorption, drug delivery, fluorescence, ion exchange, heterogeneous catealysis, and solvatochromism. Most of these properties rely on the sizes of the pores or channels in MOFs. And interpenetration or not is the key factor to affect the sizes of potential channels. Many groups have realized how to control interpenetration, though it is challenging. The construction of networks with interpenetration is based on supramolecular interactions, such as van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonding, and π-π stacking, not via chemical bonds. However, the interpenetrated networks cannot be separated without breakage of bonds. To our knowledge, interpenetration can be controlled via different parameters, such as reaction temperature, reaction concentration, ligands design/modification, template, coordinated or uncoordinated solvent removal/addition, and layer-by-layer assembly. As far as we know, more attention has been paid to complicated organic ligands due to their various coordinated modes and ability to produce novel structures. However, most syntheses of these ligands are fussy, which requires much effort to achieve industrialization or practical application.

elements.content: Herein, we design a simple “V-shape” semirigid ligand bis­(4-(pyridine-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (BPPA). To test its ability to give new architectures and topologies, we selected rigid coligands H2BDC, H2NDC, and TFBDC to get five new MOFs (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, TFBDC = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Compound 1 constructed of Zn­(II) is a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network with sra topology, and compound 2 consisting of Cd­(II) has a 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology. With a “longer” rigid ligand, for example, H2NDC replace H2BDC, compound 3 is obtained with a one-dimensional (1D) chain. Deprotonated methanoic acid molecules from N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) coordinate with Zn­(II), which holds back the 1D chain from further generating. Utilizing a “fatter” rigid ligand, such as the ligand TFBDC, we have successfully controlled interpenetration of frameworks. Compounds 4 and 5 are both non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 frameworks, and the 6T8 topology has rarely been reported in MOFs before.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we design a simple "V-shape" semirigid ligand bis(4-(pyridine-4-yl)phenyl)amine (BPPA). To test its ability to give new architectures and topologies, we selected rigid coligands H2BDC, H2NDC, and TFBDC to get five new MOFs (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, TFBDC = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Compound 1 constructed of Zn(II) is a 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) network with sra topology, and compound 2 consisting of Cd(II) has a 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology. With a "longer" rigid ligand, for example, H2NDC replace H2BDC, compound 3 is obtained with a one-dimensional (1D) chain. Deprotonated methanoic acid molecules from  N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) coordinate with Zn(II), which holds back the 1D chain from further generating. Utilizing a "fatter" rigid ligand, such as the ligand TFBDC, we have successfully controlled interpenetration of frameworks. Compounds 4 and 5 are both non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 frameworks, and the 6T8 topology has rarely been reported in MOFs before.

elements.content: Besides, in compounds 1–5, there are various coordination modes in carboxyl groups, as shown in . And the emission decay lifetimes of compounds 4 and 5 are longer than other compounds and free ligands because of adding fluorine atoms, which show potential for developing materials with long emission decay lifetimes.
elements.clean_text: Besides, in compounds 1-5, there are various coordination modes in carboxyl groups, as shown in . And the emission decay lifetimes of compounds 4 and 5 are longer than other compounds and free ligands because of adding fluorine atoms, which show potential for developing materials with long emission decay lifetimes.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P2 1 /c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1 includes two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, two BPPA ligands, two deprotonated H2BDC, and six free water molecules, which were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. As shown in Figure a, ligand H2BDC prefers monodentate modes (modes I of ). Both the Zn1 and Zn2 are tetrahedrally coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two H2BDC ligands and two nitrogen atoms belonging to two BPPA ligands. The Zn–O distances range from 1.933(4) to 1.958(4) Å, and Zn–N distances range from 1.973(5) to 2.028(4) Å. The H2BDC ligands connect with Zn centers to furnish a 1D curved chain, and the BPPA ligands bridge those 1D chains to directly form a 3D structure. The 3D framework consists of two kinds of channels, namely, A and B, along the c axis (Figure b). The potential voids are large enough to cause 4-fold interpenetration of the networks. To better understand the nature of this framework, a TOPOS analysis is provided by software TOPOS4.0. As shown in Figure d, the interpenetration of 1 can be classified as type IIIa, Z = 4 (Zt = 2; Zn = 2). Topologically, the Zn centers act as 4-connnected nodes, and H2BDC and BPPA ligands as linkers. Compound 1 represents 4-connected sra net with a point symbol of (42.63.8) (Figure c,d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(BPPA)2(BDC)2]⋅6H2O} n  (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P2 1 /c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1 includes two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, two BPPA ligands, two deprotonated H2BDC, and six free water molecules, which were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. As shown in Figure a, ligand H2BDC prefers monodentate modes (modes I of ). Both the Zn1 and Zn2 are tetrahedrally coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two H2BDC ligands and two nitrogen atoms belonging to two BPPA ligands. The Zn-O distances range from 1.933(4) to 1.958(4) Å, and Zn-N distances range from 1.973(5) to 2.028(4) Å. The H2BDC ligands connect with Zn centers to furnish a 1D curved chain, and the BPPA ligands bridge those 1D chains to directly form a 3D structure. The 3D framework consists of two kinds of channels, namely, A and B, along the c axis (Figure b). The potential voids are large enough to cause 4-fold interpenetration of the networks. To better understand the nature of this framework, a TOPOS analysis is provided by software TOPOS4.0. As shown in Figure d, the interpenetration of 1 can be classified as type IIIa, Z = 4 (Zt = 2; Zn = 2). Topologically, the Zn centers act as 4-connnected nodes, and H2BDC and BPPA ligands as linkers. Compound 1 represents 4-connected sra net with a point symbol of (42.63.8) (Figure c,d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ions in 1. The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z, #2 = −1 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z. (b) Perspective views of 3D structure of 1 (along the c axis). (c) Schematic views of a single 3D framework of compound 1. (d) Schematic representation of 4-fold interpenetrated framework of 1.

(d) Schematic representation of 4-fold interpenetrated framework of 1.

“R 1” = Σ∥F 0| – |F c∥/|Σ|F 0|. “wR 2” = {Σ­[w(F 0 2 – F c 2)2]/Σ­[w(F 0 2)2]}1/2; where w = 1/[σ2(F o 2) + (aP)2 + bP], P = (F o 2 + 2F c 2)/3.

Compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of the Pbcn space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of three crystallographically independent Cd cations, one BPPA ligand, three BDC2– ions, two coordinated DMF molecules, three lattice water molecules, and one free DMF molecule. All the lattice molecules were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The carboxylate groups of H2BDC ligand take two different coordination modes (modes II and III of ). As shown in Figure a, the coordination geometry of Cd1 and Cd3 are both pentagonal bipyramids. Each pentagonal bipyramid is defined by six O atoms and one N atom. In this pentagonal bipyramid, four O atoms from two carboxylate groups of BDC2– and one N atom from BPPA form the equatorial plane, and one O atom from BDC2– ions and one N atom from BPPA respectively locate the two axial positions. Cd2 is octahedrally coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate groups of BDC2– anions. Of which, four carboxylate groups take the μ3 chelating-bridging tridentate modes to bridge Cd1 and Cd2 or Cd2 and Cd3, and the other two adopt bimonodentate chelating coordination modes to link Cd1–Cd2 or Cd2–Cd3. In this way, Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3 generate trinuclear Cd­(II) second building units (SBUs) in compound 2. As far as we know, trinuclear Cd­(II) SBUs are common in MOFs, but reports of them adopting the same coordination modes are rare. The previous reported trinuclear Cd­(II) are all coordinated by O atoms. The distance of Cd1–Cd2 is about 3.575 Å, and the distance of Cd2–Cd3 is approximately 3.639 Å. The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range 2.184(3)–2.515(3) Å, and the Cd–N bond lengths are in the range 2.288(3)–2.298(4) Å. If BPPA ligands are ignored, the carboxylate groups of BDC2– anions link trinuclear Cd­(II) SBUs to develop a two-dimensional (2D) layered network (Figure b). The 2D layered network concatenates another 2D layer via the N atoms from BPPA ligands to further form a 3D framework (Figure c,d). By topology analysis, the trinuclear Cd­(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, and compound 2 represents sxa topology with a point symbol of (42.67) (Figure e,f). As shown in Figure d,f, the interpenetration of 2 can be classified as type IIa, Z = 2 (Zt = 1; Zn = 2). According to TTD/TTO database, the 2-fold interpenetrating sxa nets in 2 are quite different from the previous reported compounds with the same topology, which are all non-interpenetration interpenetrating sxa nets.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Cd3(BPPA)(BDC)3(DMF)2]⋅DMF⋅3H2O} n  (2)

Compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of the Pbcn space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of three crystallographically independent Cd cations, one BPPA ligand, three BDC2- ions, two coordinated DMF molecules, three lattice water molecules, and one free DMF molecule. All the lattice molecules were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The carboxylate groups of H2BDC ligand take two different coordination modes (modes II and III of ). As shown in Figure a, the coordination geometry of Cd1 and Cd3 are both pentagonal bipyramids. Each pentagonal bipyramid is defined by six O atoms and one N atom. In this pentagonal bipyramid, four O atoms from two carboxylate groups of BDC2- and one N atom from BPPA form the equatorial plane, and one O atom from BDC2- ions and one N atom from BPPA respectively locate the two axial positions. Cd2 is octahedrally coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate groups of BDC2- anions. Of which, four carboxylate groups take the μ3 chelating-bridging tridentate modes to bridge Cd1 and Cd2 or Cd2 and Cd3, and the other two adopt bimonodentate chelating coordination modes to link Cd1-Cd2 or Cd2-Cd3. In this way, Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3 generate trinuclear Cd(II) second building units (SBUs) in compound 2. As far as we know, trinuclear Cd(II) SBUs are common in MOFs, but reports of them adopting the same coordination modes are rare. The previous reported trinuclear Cd(II) are all coordinated by O atoms. The distance of Cd1-Cd2 is about 3.575 Å, and the distance of Cd2-Cd3 is approximately 3.639 Å. The Cd-O bond lengths are in the range 2.184(3)-2.515(3) Å, and the Cd-N bond lengths are in the range 2.288(3)-2.298(4) Å. If BPPA ligands are ignored, the carboxylate groups of BDC2- anions link trinuclear Cd(II) SBUs to develop a two-dimensional (2D) layered network (Figure b). The 2D layered network concatenates another 2D layer via the N atoms from BPPA ligands to further form a 3D framework (Figure c,d). By topology analysis, the trinuclear Cd(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, and compound 2 represents sxa topology with a point symbol of (42.67) (Figure e,f). As shown in Figure d,f, the interpenetration of 2 can be classified as type IIa, Z = 2 (Zt = 1; Zn = 2). According to TTD/TTO database, the 2-fold interpenetrating sxa nets in 2 are quite different from the previous reported compounds with the same topology, which are all non-interpenetration interpenetrating sxa nets.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit of 3 contains one Zn cation, one BPPA ligand, 1/2 deprotonated H2NDC, and one coordinated methanoic acid molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Zn1 is five-coordinated by two O from one H2NDC (modes IV of ), one O belonging to deprotonated methanoic acid, and two N from two different BPPA ligands. The Zn–O distances ranges from 1.9506(19) to 2.548(2) Å, and Zn–N distances ranges from 2.022(2) to 2.0546(18) Å. Each Zn1 binds two adjacent BPPA to form a 1D chain, and two neighboring 1D chains via NDC2– anions generate a new 1D chain (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn(BPPA)(NDC)1/2(HCO2)]} n  (3)

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit of 3 contains one Zn cation, one BPPA ligand, 1/2 deprotonated H2NDC, and one coordinated methanoic acid molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Zn1 is five-coordinated by two O from one H2NDC (modes IV of ), one O belonging to deprotonated methanoic acid, and two N from two different BPPA ligands. The Zn-O distances ranges from 1.9506(19) to 2.548(2) Å, and Zn-N distances ranges from 2.022(2) to 2.0546(18) Å. Each Zn1 binds two adjacent BPPA to form a 1D chain, and two neighboring 1D chains via NDC2- anions generate a new 1D chain (Figure b).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ions in 3. The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = x, −1 + y, −1 + z. (b) Views of the 1D chain.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environment of the Zn(II) ions in 3. The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = x, -1 + y, -1 + z. (b) Views of the 1D chain.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 4, it is composed of three crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions, three BPPA ligands, three TFBDC ligands, and one lattice water molecule. The coordination environment of Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 are similar. All Zn centers are five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three TFBDC ligands and two nitrogen atoms from BPPA ligands with the Zn–O distances ranging from 1.9923(19) to 2.092(2) Å and Zn–N distances ranging from 2.101(2) to 2.175(2) Å (Figure a). Zn1 and Zn1#3 (symmetry codes: #3 = 0.5 – x, −0.5 – y, – z), Zn2 and Zn3 are respectively bridged by carboxylate groups adopting bismonodentate coordination modes (modes V of ) to form paddle-wheel [Zn2(CO2)4] SBUs. TFBDC ligands connect adjacent binuclear SBUs to generate a 2D layer (Figure b), which take bismonodentate coordination modes and bidentate chelating coordination modes (modes V and VI of ). These 2D layers are linked each other via ligand BPPA to further form a 3D framework (Figure c). Topologically, each SBU can act as a 6-connected node, and compound 4 can be represented as a 6T8 topology, with a point symbol of (44.611) (Figure d). It is interesting that this uninodal 6T8 topology has seldom been seen in MOFs or Coordination Polymers(CPs).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn3(BPPA)3(TFBDC)3]⋅H2O} n  (4)

Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of 4, it is composed of three crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, three BPPA ligands, three TFBDC ligands, and one lattice water molecule. The coordination environment of Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 are similar. All Zn centers are five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three TFBDC ligands and two nitrogen atoms from BPPA ligands with the Zn-O distances ranging from 1.9923(19) to 2.092(2) Å and Zn-N distances ranging from 2.101(2) to 2.175(2) Å (Figure a). Zn1 and Zn1#3 (symmetry codes: #3 = 0.5 - x, -0.5 - y, - z), Zn2 and Zn3 are respectively bridged by carboxylate groups adopting bismonodentate coordination modes (modes V of ) to form paddle-wheel [Zn2(CO2)4] SBUs. TFBDC ligands connect adjacent binuclear SBUs to generate a 2D layer (Figure b), which take bismonodentate coordination modes and bidentate chelating coordination modes (modes V and VI of ). These 2D layers are linked each other via ligand BPPA to further form a 3D framework (Figure c). Topologically, each SBU can act as a 6-connected node, and compound 4 can be represented as a 6T8 topology, with a point symbol of (44.611) (Figure d). It is interesting that this uninodal 6T8 topology has seldom been seen in MOFs or Coordination Polymers(CPs).

Symmetry codes: #1 = -0.5 + x, -0.5 - y, -0.5 + z, #2 = 0.5 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z, #3 = 0.5 - x, -0.5 - y, - z. (b) A view of the 2D network by TFBDC and Zn cations. (c) A perspective of 3D architecture of 4 along the a axis. (d) Schematic representation of the 6-connected 3D framework of 4.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group, which is same as compound 4. Besides, they have the uniform topology type 6T8 (Figure d). In compound 5, the asymmetric unit has two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) cations, two BPPA ligands, and two TFBDC ligands. As shown in Figure a, each Cd atom is in a “4 + 2” distorted octahedral coordination sphere. The four O atoms from three different TFBDC ligands locate in the equatorial plane, and two N atoms from two BPPA ligands occupy the axial positions. The carboxylate groups adopt bismonodentate and bidentate chelating coordination modes (modes V and VI of ) to connect two Cd centers to generate paddle-wheel [Cd2(CO2)4] SBUs, and the distance between Cd1 and Cd2 is 4.016 Å. The carboxylate groups of TFBDC ligands bridge the dinuclear Cd­(II) SBUs to construct a 2D layered nework (Figure b), and the 2D layer connects adjacent 2D layers to result in a 3D structure (Figure c). The paddle-wheel Cd­(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connnect nodes, and ligands can be considered as linkers. The overall framework of 5 also displays a 6-connnect 6T8 net like compound 4.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Cd2(BPPA)2(TFBDC)2]} n  (5)

Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group, which is same as compound 4. Besides, they have the uniform topology type 6T8 (Figure d). In compound 5, the asymmetric unit has two crystallographically independent Cd(II) cations, two BPPA ligands, and two TFBDC ligands. As shown in Figure a, each Cd atom is in a "4 + 2" distorted octahedral coordination sphere. The four O atoms from three different TFBDC ligands locate in the equatorial plane, and two N atoms from two BPPA ligands occupy the axial positions. The carboxylate groups adopt bismonodentate and bidentate chelating coordination modes (modes V and VI of ) to connect two Cd centers to generate paddle-wheel [Cd2(CO2)4] SBUs, and the distance between Cd1 and Cd2 is 4.016 Å. The carboxylate groups of TFBDC ligands bridge the dinuclear Cd(II) SBUs to construct a 2D layered nework (Figure b), and the 2D layer connects adjacent 2D layers to result in a 3D structure (Figure c). The paddle-wheel Cd(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connnect nodes, and ligands can be considered as linkers. The overall framework of 5 also displays a 6-connnect 6T8 net like compound 4.

elements.content: (a). Coordination environment of the Cd­(II) ion in 5. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = −1 + x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z, #2 = 1 + x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z. (b) A view of the 2D network by TFBDC ligand and Cd cations. (c) A perspective of 3D framework of 5. (d) Schematic representation of the 6-connnected 3D architecture of 5.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a). Coordination environment of the Cd(II) ion in 5. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = -1 + x, 1.5 - y, 0.5 + z, #2 = 1 + x, 1.5 - y, 0.5 + z. (b) A view of the 2D network by TFBDC ligand and Cd cations. (c) A perspective of 3D framework of 5. (d) Schematic representation of the 6-connnected 3D architecture of 5.

elements.content: In this work, the structures of coligands are key factors in controlling interpenetration of frameworks. The reaction conditions of 1–5 are almost the same, such as the reaction temperature, the reaction time, the solvent system, and the reactant proportion except different coligands. The H2BDC ligand acts as a coligand in compounds 1 and 2, while in compound 3 coligand is H2NDC ligand, and it is TFBDC ligand in 4 and 5. From H2BDC ligand to H2NDC, naphthalene rings replacing benzene rings can be regarded as the length of ligands increased. Compared with H2BDC, four fluorine atoms in TFBDC take the place of four hydrogen atoms on the benzene ring, which can be considered as a “fatter”coligand.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of the Compounds and Comparisons of the Crystal Structures

In this work, the structures of coligands are key factors in controlling interpenetration of frameworks. The reaction conditions of 1-5 are almost the same, such as the reaction temperature, the reaction time, the solvent system, and the reactant proportion except different coligands. The H2BDC ligand acts as a coligand in compounds 1 and 2, while in compound 3 coligand is H2NDC ligand, and it is TFBDC ligand in 4 and 5. From H2BDC ligand to H2NDC, naphthalene rings replacing benzene rings can be regarded as the length of ligands increased. Compared with H2BDC, four fluorine atoms in TFBDC take the place of four hydrogen atoms on the benzene ring, which can be considered as a "fatter"coligand.

elements.content: In compounds 1 and 2, BPPA ligands are longer than H2BDC, and they both coordinate with metal centers forming large channels in frameworks. Besides, BPPA is a typical kind of “V-shape” ligand, easy to distort in structure with large potential voids to generate varying degrees of interpenetration in frameworks. The framework of 1 contains two kinds of channels (Figure b). One is an irregular hexagonal channel with a size of 40.10 × 28.62 Å (along two diagonal lines), containing six Zn atoms, four H2BDC ligands, and two BPPA ligands. The other is a rectangular channel with a size of 22.64 × 20.65 Å (along two diagonal lines), which is formed by two H2BDC ligands and two BPPA ligands alternately bridging four Zn atoms. The potential voids are so large that 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrating topology (Figure c). As shown in Figure c, 2 has a distorted rectangular channel with a size of 22.40 × 20.55 Å (along two diagonal lines). These large potential voids result in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture of 2 (Figure d). In a word, compounds 1 and 2 have different degrees of interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: In compounds 1 and 2, BPPA ligands are longer than H2BDC, and they both coordinate with metal centers forming large channels in frameworks. Besides, BPPA is a typical kind of "V-shape" ligand, easy to distort in structure with large potential voids to generate varying degrees of interpenetration in frameworks. The framework of 1 contains two kinds of channels (Figure b). One is an irregular hexagonal channel with a size of 40.10 × 28.62 Å (along two diagonal lines), containing six Zn atoms, four H2BDC ligands, and two BPPA ligands. The other is a rectangular channel with a size of 22.64 × 20.65 Å (along two diagonal lines), which is formed by two H2BDC ligands and two BPPA ligands alternately bridging four Zn atoms. The potential voids are so large that 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrating topology (Figure c). As shown in Figure c, 2 has a distorted rectangular channel with a size of 22.40 × 20.55 Å (along two diagonal lines). These large potential voids result in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture of 2 (Figure d). In a word, compounds 1 and 2 have different degrees of interpenetration.

elements.content: The attendant problem is how to effectively control interpenetration. In the beginning, we planned to approach it via a longer coligand, such as H2NDC. However, compound 3 is a 1D chain, which is not our expectation. This is because DMF molecules effortlessly decompose into formic acid molecules to coordinate with Zn atoms even in the similar reaction conditions. The second way is controlling interpenetration by a “fatter” ligand, such as TFBDC. The stereohindrance effect of fluorine atoms are greater than hydrogen atoms, and the potential channels may be smaller, which may prevent interpenetration from occurring. In Figures c and c, it is obvious that adding fluorine atoms occupy some voids, and the sizes of channels in 4 and 5 respectively are 19.49 × 16.84 Å and 13.69 × 16.84 Å (along two diagonal lines). They are smaller than those in 1 and 2, which just allows BPPA to link Zn/Cd centers and prevent interpenetrating. The results correspond to our conjectures. In fact, the whole structures of compounds 4 and 5 are both represented as 6T8 topology with non-interpenetration (Figures d and d).
elements.clean_text: The attendant problem is how to effectively control interpenetration. In the beginning, we planned to approach it via a longer coligand, such as H2NDC. However, compound 3 is a 1D chain, which is not our expectation. This is because DMF molecules effortlessly decompose into formic acid molecules to coordinate with Zn atoms even in the similar reaction conditions. The second way is controlling interpenetration by a "fatter" ligand, such as TFBDC. The stereohindrance effect of fluorine atoms are greater than hydrogen atoms, and the potential channels may be smaller, which may prevent interpenetration from occurring. In Figures c and c, it is obvious that adding fluorine atoms occupy some voids, and the sizes of channels in 4 and 5 respectively are 19.49 × 16.84 Å and 13.69 × 16.84 Å (along two diagonal lines). They are smaller than those in 1 and 2, which just allows BPPA to link Zn/Cd centers and prevent interpenetrating. The results correspond to our conjectures. In fact, the whole structures of compounds 4 and 5 are both represented as 6T8 topology with non-interpenetration (Figures d and d).

elements.content: To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TGA were carried out (). For compound 1, a gradual weight loss of 8.42% (calcd 8.90%) is observed from 20 to approximately 225 °C, which is assigned to the loss of six lattice water molecules, and after that the decomposition of the compound 1 starts. The TGA curve of 2 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of 8.91% between 70 and 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one free DMF molecule and three lattice water molecules (calcd 8.91%). Then the network of 2 subsequently collapses. For compound 3, there is a gradual weight loss of 8.16% (calcd 8.15%) from 20 to 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one coordination formic acid molecule. Afterward, the frameworks of 3 begin decompose. In compound 4, an insignificant weight loss of 0.95% from 20 to 110 °C corresponds to the loss of one free water molecule (calcd 0.94%). Above 250 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed due to the burning of the organic ligands. The TGA study of compound 5 indicates no obvious weight loss from 20 to 320 °C, suggesting that the frameworks are thermally stable. Then above 320 °C, there is a sharp weight loss, which is ascribed to the decomposition of 5.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TGA were carried out (). For compound 1, a gradual weight loss of 8.42% (calcd 8.90%) is observed from 20 to approximately 225 °C, which is assigned to the loss of six lattice water molecules, and after that the decomposition of the compound 1 starts. The TGA curve of 2 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of 8.91% between 70 and 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one free DMF molecule and three lattice water molecules (calcd 8.91%). Then the network of 2 subsequently collapses. For compound 3, there is a gradual weight loss of 8.16% (calcd 8.15%) from 20 to 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one coordination formic acid molecule. Afterward, the frameworks of 3 begin decompose. In compound 4, an insignificant weight loss of 0.95% from 20 to 110 °C corresponds to the loss of one free water molecule (calcd 0.94%). Above 250 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed due to the burning of the organic ligands. The TGA study of compound 5 indicates no obvious weight loss from 20 to 320 °C, suggesting that the frameworks are thermally stable. Then above 320 °C, there is a sharp weight loss, which is ascribed to the decomposition of 5.

elements.content: To confirm the purities of compounds 1–5, X-ray power diffraction analyses were carried out. The experimental spectra of compounds 1–5 are nearly consistent with their simulated spectra (), which indicate that compounds 1–5 have been successfully obtained as pure crystalline.
elements.clean_text: To confirm the purities of compounds 1-5, X-ray power diffraction analyses were carried out. The experimental spectra of compounds 1-5 are nearly consistent with their simulated spectra (), which indicate that compounds 1-5 have been successfully obtained as pure crystalline.

elements.content: As shown in Figure and , the solid-state luminescence of compounds 1–5, and the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands are investigated at room temperature. The fluorescent emission band of BPPA ligands at λem = 457 nm under λex = 270 nm can be assigned to the π* → π or π* → n electronic transitions, so do as TFBDC (λem = 423 nm under λex = 366 nm). What’s more, the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands exhibit blue or purple emission, while these coordination polymers have strong yellow fluorescence emission in the region of 450–570 nm with a broad band. Comparing with the emission spectra of BPPA and TFBDC ligands, these coordination polymers are all pronounced red-shifted. The emission peaks of compounds 1–3 are red-shifted 101, 69 and 90 nm, respectively. The emission spectra of compounds 4 and 5 show that the emission peak centers are respectively at 542 and 519 nm. The significant red-shifted emission bands can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences among the band positions of these compounds may be attributed to the different metal centers, various coordination environments, or the differences in the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. Compared with ligands, the obvious stronger fluorescence of MOFs might be related to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

As shown in Figure  and , the solid-state luminescence of compounds 1-5, and the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands are investigated at room temperature. The fluorescent emission band of BPPA ligands at λem = 457 nm under λex = 270 nm can be assigned to the π* → π or π* → n electronic transitions, so do as TFBDC (λem = 423 nm under λex = 366 nm). What's more, the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands exhibit blue or purple emission, while these coordination polymers have strong yellow fluorescence emission in the region of 450-570 nm with a broad band. Comparing with the emission spectra of BPPA and TFBDC ligands, these coordination polymers are all pronounced red-shifted. The emission peaks of compounds 1-3 are red-shifted 101, 69 and 90 nm, respectively. The emission spectra of compounds 4 and 5 show that the emission peak centers are respectively at 542 and 519 nm. The significant red-shifted emission bands can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences among the band positions of these compounds may be attributed to the different metal centers, various coordination environments, or the differences in the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. Compared with ligands, the obvious stronger fluorescence of MOFs might be related to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligands.

elements.content: Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of 1–5 and corresponding ligands at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 6  Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of 1-5 and corresponding ligands at room temperature.

elements.content: Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of these compounds were investigated, and the curves (, Supporting Information) are best fitted by biexponentials in the solid. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 0.20 μs (10.73%), τ2 = 1.76 μs (89.27%) (χ2 = 1.053) for BPPA ligands, τ1 = 1.07 μs (28.83%), τ2 = 3.44 μs (71.17%) (χ2 = 1.195) for TFBDC ligands, τ1 = 1.50 μs (64.30%), τ2 = 4.32 μs (35.70%) (χ2 = 1.164) for compound 1, τ1 = 1.06 μs (57.74%), τ2 = 5.18 μs (42.26%) (χ2 = 2.012) for compound 2, τ1 = 1.70 μs (55.57%), τ2 = 5.93 μs (44.43%) (χ2 = 1.006) for compound 3, τ1 = 3.31 μs (53.72%), τ2 = 13.18 μs (46.28%) (χ2 = 1.306) for compound 4, and τ1 = 3.02 μs (69.62%), τ2 = 12.72 μs (30.38%) (χ2 = 1.345) for compound 5. Obviously, the lifetimes of compounds 4 and 5 are longer than other compounds and free ligands, which can be due to the fluorescent synergistic effect. This may be significant to luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of these compounds were investigated, and the curves (, Supporting Information) are best fitted by biexponentials in the solid. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 0.20 μs (10.73%), τ2 = 1.76 μs (89.27%) (χ2 = 1.053) for BPPA ligands, τ1 = 1.07 μs (28.83%), τ2 = 3.44 μs (71.17%) (χ2 = 1.195) for TFBDC ligands, τ1 = 1.50 μs (64.30%), τ2 = 4.32 μs (35.70%) (χ2 = 1.164) for compound 1, τ1 = 1.06 μs (57.74%), τ2 = 5.18 μs (42.26%) (χ2 = 2.012) for compound 2, τ1 = 1.70 μs (55.57%), τ2 = 5.93 μs (44.43%) (χ2 = 1.006) for compound 3, τ1 = 3.31 μs (53.72%), τ2 = 13.18 μs (46.28%) (χ2 = 1.306) for compound 4, and τ1 = 3.02 μs (69.62%), τ2 = 12.72 μs (30.38%) (χ2 = 1.345) for compound 5. Obviously, the lifetimes of compounds 4 and 5 are longer than other compounds and free ligands, which can be due to the fluorescent synergistic effect. This may be significant to luminescent materials.

elements.content: In summary, we successfully synthesized five new MOFs, which were constructed from a simple “V-shape” BPPA ligand in the presence of coligands and Zn/Cd ions under similar hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrated 3D network with sra topology. When changing the Zn­(II) to Cd­(II) cation, compound 2 is obtained, which has the first 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology. By adjusting the length of coligands from H2BDC to H2NDC, we obtain compound 3, which is a 1D chain. Utilizing a “fatter” coligand TFBDC, we successfully controlled interpenetration. And 4 and 5 have a non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 framework. Particularly, 6T8 topology has rarely been observed in MOFs/CPs before. The present results might be useful for future controlling interpenetration in porous MOFs. In addition, luminescent properties of 1–5 have also been tested. The longer emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 show that adding fluorine atoms increases the emission decay lifetime, which may have implications for developing or modifying phosphorescent materials with a long emission decay lifetime.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we successfully synthesized five new MOFs, which were constructed from a simple "V-shape" BPPA ligand in the presence of coligands and Zn/Cd ions under similar hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrated 3D network with sra topology. When changing the Zn(II) to Cd(II) cation, compound 2 is obtained, which has the first 2-fold interpenetrated sxa topology. By adjusting the length of coligands from H2BDC to H2NDC, we obtain compound 3, which is a 1D chain. Utilizing a "fatter" coligand TFBDC, we successfully controlled interpenetration. And 4 and 5 have a non-interpenetrated 3D 6T8 framework. Particularly, 6T8 topology has rarely been observed in MOFs/CPs before. The present results might be useful for future controlling interpenetration in porous MOFs. In addition, luminescent properties of 1-5 have also been tested. The longer emission decay lifetimes of 4 and 5 show that adding fluorine atoms increases the emission decay lifetime, which may have implications for developing or modifying phosphorescent materials with a long emission decay lifetime.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format, selected bond lengths and angles, IR, TGA, PXRD, and patterns of photochemistry. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
In compounds 1 and 2, BPPA ligands are longer than H2BDC, and they both coordinate with metal centers forming large channels in frameworks. Besides, BPPA is a typical kind of “V-shape” ligand, easy to distort in structure with large potential voids to generate varying degrees of interpenetration in frameworks. The framework of 1 contains two kinds of channels (Figure b). One is an irregular hexagonal channel with a size of 40.10 × 28.62 Å (along two diagonal lines), containing six Zn atoms, four H2BDC ligands, and two BPPA ligands. The other is a rectangular channel with a size of 22.64 × 20.65 Å (along two diagonal lines), which is formed by two H2BDC ligands and two BPPA ligands alternately bridging four Zn atoms. The potential voids are so large that 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrating topology (Figure c). As shown in Figure c, 2 has a distorted rectangular channel with a size of 22.40 × 20.55 Å (along two diagonal lines). These large potential voids result in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture of 2 (Figure d). In a word, compounds 1 and 2 have different degrees of interpenetration.

Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TGA were carried out (). For compound 1, a gradual weight loss of 8.42% (calcd 8.90%) is observed from 20 to approximately 225 °C, which is assigned to the loss of six lattice water molecules, and after that the decomposition of the compound 1 starts. The TGA curve of 2 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of 8.91% between 70 and 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one free DMF molecule and three lattice water molecules (calcd 8.91%). Then the network of 2 subsequently collapses. For compound 3, there is a gradual weight loss of 8.16% (calcd 8.15%) from 20 to 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one coordination formic acid molecule. Afterward, the frameworks of 3 begin decompose. In compound 4, an insignificant weight loss of 0.95% from 20 to 110 °C corresponds to the loss of one free water molecule (calcd 0.94%). Above 250 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed due to the burning of the organic ligands. The TGA study of compound 5 indicates no obvious weight loss from 20 to 320 °C, suggesting that the frameworks are thermally stable. Then above 320 °C, there is a sharp weight loss, which is ascribed to the decomposition of 5.

Luminescent Properties

As shown in Figure and , the solid-state luminescence of compounds 1–5, and the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands are investigated at room temperature. The fluorescent emission band of BPPA ligands at λem = 457 nm under λex = 270 nm can be assigned to the π* → π or π* → n electronic transitions, so do as TFBDC (λem = 423 nm under λex = 366 nm). What’s more, the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands exhibit blue or purple emission, while these coordination polymers have strong yellow fluorescence emission in the region of 450–570 nm with a broad band. Comparing with the emission spectra of BPPA and TFBDC ligands, these coordination polymers are all pronounced red-shifted. The emission peaks of compounds 1–3 are red-shifted 101, 69 and 90 nm, respectively. The emission spectra of compounds 4 and 5 show that the emission peak centers are respectively at 542 and 519 nm. The significant red-shifted emission bands can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences among the band positions of these compounds may be attributed to the different metal centers, various coordination environments, or the differences in the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. Compared with ligands, the obvious stronger fluorescence of MOFs might be related to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligands.

In compounds 1 and 2, BPPA ligands are longer than H2BDC, and they both coordinate with metal centers forming large channels in frameworks. Besides, BPPA is a typical kind of "V-shape" ligand, easy to distort in structure with large potential voids to generate varying degrees of interpenetration in frameworks. The framework of 1 contains two kinds of channels (Figure b). One is an irregular hexagonal channel with a size of 40.10 × 28.62 Å (along two diagonal lines), containing six Zn atoms, four H2BDC ligands, and two BPPA ligands. The other is a rectangular channel with a size of 22.64 × 20.65 Å (along two diagonal lines), which is formed by two H2BDC ligands and two BPPA ligands alternately bridging four Zn atoms. The potential voids are so large that 1 has a 4-fold interpenetrating topology (Figure c). As shown in Figure c, 2 has a distorted rectangular channel with a size of 22.40 × 20.55 Å (along two diagonal lines). These large potential voids result in a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture of 2 (Figure d). In a word, compounds 1 and 2 have different degrees of interpenetration.

Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TGA were carried out (). For compound 1, a gradual weight loss of 8.42% (calcd 8.90%) is observed from 20 to approximately 225 °C, which is assigned to the loss of six lattice water molecules, and after that the decomposition of the compound 1 starts. The TGA curve of 2 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of 8.91% between 70 and 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one free DMF molecule and three lattice water molecules (calcd 8.91%). Then the network of 2 subsequently collapses. For compound 3, there is a gradual weight loss of 8.16% (calcd 8.15%) from 20 to 260 °C, corresponding to the loss of one coordination formic acid molecule. Afterward, the frameworks of 3 begin decompose. In compound 4, an insignificant weight loss of 0.95% from 20 to 110 °C corresponds to the loss of one free water molecule (calcd 0.94%). Above 250 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed due to the burning of the organic ligands. The TGA study of compound 5 indicates no obvious weight loss from 20 to 320 °C, suggesting that the frameworks are thermally stable. Then above 320 °C, there is a sharp weight loss, which is ascribed to the decomposition of 5.

Luminescent Properties

As shown in Figure  and , the solid-state luminescence of compounds 1-5, and the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands are investigated at room temperature. The fluorescent emission band of BPPA ligands at λem = 457 nm under λex = 270 nm can be assigned to the π* → π or π* → n electronic transitions, so do as TFBDC (λem = 423 nm under λex = 366 nm). What's more, the free BPPA and TFBDC ligands exhibit blue or purple emission, while these coordination polymers have strong yellow fluorescence emission in the region of 450-570 nm with a broad band. Comparing with the emission spectra of BPPA and TFBDC ligands, these coordination polymers are all pronounced red-shifted. The emission peaks of compounds 1-3 are red-shifted 101, 69 and 90 nm, respectively. The emission spectra of compounds 4 and 5 show that the emission peak centers are respectively at 542 and 519 nm. The significant red-shifted emission bands can be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences among the band positions of these compounds may be attributed to the different metal centers, various coordination environments, or the differences in the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. Compared with ligands, the obvious stronger fluorescence of MOFs might be related to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligands.

(a) Coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ions in 1. The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z, #2 = −1 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z. (b) Perspective views of 3D structure of 1 (along the c axis). (c) Schematic views of a single 3D framework of compound 1. (d) Schematic representation of 4-fold interpenetrated framework of 1.

metadata.title:
Syntheses, Characterizations, Luminescent Properties,
and Controlling Interpenetration of Five Metal–Organic Frameworks
Based on Bis(4-(pyridine-4-yl)phenyl)amine
